window_tax_timeline.title: Window Tax Introduction and Evolution (1696-1851)
window_tax_timeline.description: Complete timeline of England's notorious Window Tax from financial crisis to abolition

events.description: England at war with France, draining royal treasury and requiring constant military funding
Nearly half of silver coins clipped, 10% of currency forged, monetary system near collapse

events.event: Act for Remedying the Ill State of the Coin
events.description: Parliament passes emergency legislation to address currency crisis
Clipped coins officially no longer legal tender
Clipped coins no longer accepted for tax payments
Parliament passes Window Tax Act: 2 shillings flat rate, plus 4 shillings (10-20 windows), 8 shillings (20+ windows)
'Window peepers' begin counting windows from outside buildings, first tax payments collected
First documented cases of windows being bricked up to avoid taxation
New rates: No tax under 10 windows, 6p (10-14), 9p (15-19), 1s (20+). 20 shilling penalty for reopening blocked windows
Prime Minister William Pitt raises window tax rates to compensate for reduced tea taxes
Pitt triples window tax rates to fund Napoleonic Wars
Citizens block thousands of windows overnight, write 'Lighten our darkness we beseech thee, O Pitt!' in chalk
Medical studies document increased dysentery, gangrene, typhus in poorly ventilated buildings
Charles Dickens publishes 'Health by Act of Parliament' in Household Words magazine
Parliamentary motion to repeal window tax fails by only three votes
Nationwide movement against tax gains momentum, doctors join health arguments
Window Tax officially repealed after 155 years, replaced with inhabited house tax
